title: Sugar Cain
text:
Merritt Patrick "Sugar" Cain (April 5, 1907 – April 3, 1975) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> who worked in 178 <a href="games%20pitched">games</a> in the major leagues as a member of the <a href="Philadelphia%20Athletics">Philadelphia Athletics</a> (–), <a href="St.%20Louis%20Browns">St. Louis Browns</a> (1935–) and <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a> (1936–). The native of <a href="Macon%2C%20Georgia">Macon, Georgia</a>, batted left-handed and threw right-handed, stood tall and weighed .
Over three-quarters of Cain's <a href="MLB">MLB</a> appearances came as a <a href="starting%20pitcher">starting pitcher</a>, and during his career, he amassed 58 <a href="complete%20game">complete game</a>s and two <a href="shutout%20%28baseball%29">shutouts</a>. Although his <a href="win-loss%20record%20%28pitching%29">won–lost record</a> was only 53–60 (<a href="winning%20percentage">.469</a>) with an <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a> of 4.83, he posted seasons of 13 () and 15 (1936) wins. However, Cain exhibited poor control of his repertoire, allowing more than 100 <a href="bases%20on%20balls">bases on balls</a> for three straight seasons (1933–1935), leading the American League in walks issued (123) in 1935, and averaging 5.2 walks per nine <a href="innings%20pitched">innings pitched</a> over his big-league career. Altogether, in 987 innings, Cain allowed 1,119 <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> and 569 bases on balls, with 279 <a href="strikeout">strikeout</a>s.
His pitching career ended in the <a href="minor%20leagues">minor leagues</a> in 1943, although he returned to the game to manage the <a href="Vidalia-Lyons%20Twins">Vidalia-Lyons Twins</a> in the Class D <a href="Georgia%20State%20League">Georgia State League</a> for part of the 1948 campaign. He died in <a href="Atlanta">Atlanta</a> on April 3, 1975, only two days before his 68th birthday.
